article_text:
BALTIMORE—In 2011, the city sold a vacant row house in East Baltimore’s Oliver neighborhood to a developer who promised to restore it within 18 months. It is still boarded up.

“It’s gotten worse,” said 60-year-old Patsy Jones, who rents the attached house next door on North Caroline Street and says rain falling through the vacant home’s collapsed roof regularly soaks her basement.

David Borinsky, who bought the house along...

twitter.description: Baltimore’s sea of vacant homes is one problem laid bare by last month’s Freddie Gray protests. Nearly 17,000 homes, or about 8% of the city’s housing stock, are deemed unfit for habitation.
twitter.creator: @scottmcalvert

image.alt: Baltimore’s blight plight: about 8% of city’s housing stock is deemed unfit for habitation

twitter.title: Baltimore Grapples With Blight Quandary
